author: Adam Kurkjian
title: Bill Belichick explains why Pats extended RB Dion Lewis to two-year deal | The Blitz | with Jeff Howe & Karen Guregian
text:
FOXBORO - The Patriots officially announced Thursday that they inked running back Dion Lewis to a two-year extension, a sign of just how far the free agent has come in his time with the team since the offseason.
Lewis impressed in training camp and the preseason and has carried that production into the regular season, rushing for 146 yards and two touchdowns while adding another 179 yards on 15 receptions.
Coach Bill Belichick expounded Friday on why Lewis earned the two-year, $4.4 million deal that carries through the 2017 season.
"I think off the field he has been great," Belichick said. "He had a great offseason for us. Works hard, is a well-conditioned player, trains hard."
Aside from his work ethic, Lewis has impressed his coach with his ability to absorb the playbook and apply it to the field.
"What we do on offense is extensive," Belichick said. "He's done a good job of learning obviously all the running back stuff, but extended play, empty plays where he's playing out the of the backfield."
And, of course, Belichick loves versatile players, and Lewis has shown an ability to be a four-down one.
"He's shown value in the kicking game," Belichick said. "He's shown value on all three downs on offense. He's done a good job of learning a lot of different spots, a lot of different adjustments, blitz pickups and so forth in the passing game."
Add to that Lewis' ability to make people miss in the open field and his "short-area quickness," as Belichick said, the commitment to Lewis makes sense.
So consider, at least for now, the Patriots more stable at a position that looked the opposite during the offseason with the losses of Shane Vereen (Giants) and Stevan Ridley (Jets).
